node.title: New locally acquired COVID case in Queensland believed to be source of Gold Coast cluster
node.alt: Queensland Health Minister Yvette D'Ath speaks at a media conference.
node.description: The man is believed to have been infectious in the community for a number of days and may have travelled in NSW.
node.content:
["Queensland has recorded one new locally acquired case of COVID-19, which authorities\u00a0believe may be the\u00a0source of the most recent Gold Coast cluster.", "The person was in the community for a number of days while infectious.", "Acting Chief Health Officer Peter Aitken said it was believed the man may have travelled interstate.", "\"We are working with that gentleman. He's been very cooperative, and trying to track his movements and work out where he's been,\" Dr Aitken said.", "\"As we get that history we'll put more venues on the website for people to check in on.\"", "Health Minister Yvette D'Ath said the rate of people getting their first dose of vaccine was slowing, with 87.4 per cent of Queenslanders over 16 having received the first jab.", "\"I say to the almost 15 per cent of eligible Queenslanders out there who are not yet vaccinated for one dose, please come out and get vaccinated,\" she said.", "\"The borders are opening on Monday and mandatory vaccination social measures come into effect on the 17th of December.\"", "Dr Aitken said the vaccination rates on the Gold Coast were still low compared to other parts of the state.", "\"The Gold Coast is an area that, as we know is adjacent to New South Wales border, and is more likely to have people moving back and forth,\" he said.", "\"One dose is better than none. Two doses better than one, [but] one still provides more protection than not being vaccinated at all and that's the really important thing.\"", "Dr Aitken said people who are not vaccinated are 16 times more likely to end up in intensive care in hospital if they catch the disease.", "
Crackdown on deliberate spitting, sneezing on workers
", "Health Minister Yvette D'Ath said the government has extended the offence of spitting, coughing, or sneezing deliberately on people to include hospitality workers.", "\"We extended that to retail workers because we know they saw appalling behaviour while they tried to just get on with doing their job and serving the community,\" Ms D'Ath said.", "\"We want to protect them from this sort of behaviour, so we will be extending this offence to protect all workers in all businesses that are bound by this public health directive.\"", "Anyone who spits, coughs or sneezes, or threatens to do so, can be given an on the spot fine of $1,378 under the direction.", "Queensland Police Commissioner Katarina Carroll said from December 17, businesses will be required to display new rules about restricting access to people who are unvaccinated.", "\"It is up to businesses and business operators to actually check that the patron meet these requirements,\" Commissioner Carroll said.", "She said police will be conducting compliance checks to ensure businesses are complying with the regulations."]
